content.body: annevk2: thanks
what should cloning a media element do?
should it clone the current source, current time, and all other internal state?
mpilgrim - diving into HTML 5 - great article
^book
mpilgrim: in the canvas chapter, where you mention 3D, you might want to mention WebGL
roc dropped off.. I was going to say that as far as mentioning WebGL it could help a lot of Mozilla and/or Khronos actually published some public information about it somewhere
last I looked I could not find anything
just a high-level overview page somewhere, and maybe some kind of status update about the progress of the discussions
and some current list of organizations who are involved in the discussions
of course what would really help is if the draft spec and the discussions themselves were actually public
but so far there doesn't seem to be much indication that's actually going to happen any time soon
(unless I missed some recent news)
MikeSmith: feel like fixing <footer> in v.nu? :)
I really, really, really wish Google stopped treating me as a lab rat on the search results page
MikeSmith: Khronos doesn't use a public process, sadly
the Apple folks in the relevant Khronos group seem to think it's going ok
http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=646
I do wish we'd used a standards org with public process for this
I'm glad to hear it's going OK at least. I think it will prove to be something extremely useful to developers

othermaciej: I guess I would just hope that those involved who have worked to help for more openness at the W3C and elsewhere (instead of on member-only lists and such) would also make an genuine effort to push for similar change for real openness there
MikeSmith: Chris Marrin of Apple is the editor of the spec, and Oliver Hunt and a few others from Apple are also involved
zcorpan: can you remind me what needs to be fixed around footer? is there an open bug? if it's an easy one I can try to get it fixed fast
MikeSmith: I expect changing Khronos would be hard - I wish a different venue had been chosen
othermaciej: ah, cool. that's good to know
Khronos also makes it very likely that Microsoft will not participate or ever adopt the spec
othermaciej: seems like it'd be pretty easy if opera, google, mozilla, and apple all said "ok let's make this a public process or we quit"
Hixie: Mozilla and Google were the main ones who pushed for the spec to be done using Khronos's known non-open process, IIRC
but I should probably join the list and get a handle on what's up
i'd be mildly surprised if google was, but ok
and i don't get why mozilla would want a closed process
but i know they were pushing khronos

othermaciej: if there wasn't open discussion about the choice of venue before that choice was made -- that is, if the choice was basically made unilaterally without much discussion among the potential implementors and other stakeholders... well, that is pretty disheartening on its own
MikeSmith: as far as I can tell, it was mainly decided by Mozilla (possibly also Google but not sure)
MikeSmith: by the time they talked to us about it, they'd already talked to Khronos and decided it was the way to go
MikeSmith: change content model to the same as <header>. don't know if there's a bug, but iirc hixie annotated the checkin as affecting validators
we'd have preferred open process, but Apple participates in Khronos a lot already so we can't really call it a bad venue
othermaciej: hmm. that seems really unfortunate but I guess I should shut about it
*shut up about it
the risk I'm afraid of is too many graphics experts and not enough web technology experts
embeds a youtube video in http://blog.whatwg.org/vim-checker with just <embed>
othermaciej: that doesn't seem like so big a risk.. I guess the quality of the representation is more important then the quantity
and sounds like you guys have the right people in their at least
Hixie: the markup youtube provides for embedding videos could be simplified
not surprised

http://codinginparadise.org/weblog/2009/09/new-svg-web-release-owlbear.html says: "SVG itself stands for Scalable Vector Graphics, an open standard that is part of the HTML 5 family of technologies for interactive, search-engine friendly web vector graphics."
MikeSmith: I'm told that at times it's hard to get people to really understand that APIs that are part of the Web platform need to be safe - you can't let bad calls cause leaks or crashes
MikeSmith: classically, OpenGL counts on the application developer to get things right
HTML 5 "family of technologies" ?
zcorpan: very cool video
HTML5 is a very flexible buzzword
zcorpan: much better then the crappy screenshot I had there before that the dog ate
the term HTML5 has market value.. other technologies should be happy to be associated with it
it seems that every five years or so, a new buzzword appears that means the same thing: DHTML, Ajax, HTML5
MikeSmith, has "HTML5" superceded "W3C" as the buzzword of choice?
was W3C ever a buzzword?
I guess "the Open Web Platform family of technologies" would be a bit long
zcorpan: it was when the WaSP started
e.g. SVG was part of the W3C family of technologies for interactive search-engine friendly web vector graphics
considers how to finesse wording for associating client-side XSLT with HTML5...
zcorpan W3C was a buzzword as long as most of the work that came out of W3C was for the Open Web Platform in practice
wonders if SVG/HTML5 is a bit like GNU/Linux from the SVG POV

othermaciej: counting on application developers to get things right doesn't seem to be the safest approach for the Web.. I'm reminded of the current discussion about mutex-like locking and also Crockord's comment "most of the world's body of JavaScript programs is crap"

when the work became primarily about "enterprise/intranet" technologies (e.g. XML*** family) rather than the public world wide web, you might say the term W3C lost favor among those who worked hard for the actual open web.
hsivonen - originally SVG was one of many efforts that was supposed to obsolete/kill HTML.
tantek: not just enterprise/intranet but also mobile not-the-real-Web and Semantic Web
tantek: interesting. SVG seems to be in a different category
MikeSmith: browsers simply can't offer APIs that let Web content cause crashes or hangs; but I'm sure it will all be worked out, it just takes a bunch of explaining at times
tantek: though the API stuff occasionally seems like ignoring what was already there
hsivonen - the mobile companies weren't fooled for long, and switched toward actual open web technologies quite quickly
tantek: I guess I think in general that the name of any one particular organization is not the best term to use as a term for promoting a particular set of technologies
MikeSmith - it should have been, given that W3C's mission was/is to lead the web to its full potential.
tantek: it turns out the Web doesn't mean what it seems to mean

othermaciej: I think the basic explanation to them should be, don't assume this stuff will be used safely and responsibly by thoughtful programmers who actually know what they are doing and won't shoot themselves in the foot
has discovered that the W3C's mission statement is very unhelpful as a frame of discussion on what the W3C should do
hsivonen - "the Web" means *the* Web, it doesn't mean a bunch of little closed webs (intranets), it also means the *existing* Web, not some future parallel universe all-cleaned-up Web.
tantek: oh, I agree with you
tantek: WAP and the rainbow spectrum of Mobile Profiles of things aren't quite dead yet...
othermaciej - the mobile profiles that diverge from actual open web technologies are dead enough. does iPhone support WAP 1.0?

tantek: someone I know once said to me, "Standards bodies don't age well." ... it is perhaps to be expected that any given standards body that's around for long enough is going to eventually do some things to seriously disappoint some of the very people who helped to build it and make it successful
tantek: iPhone does not support that stuff (as far as I know)
i think standards bodies are an outdated concept
othermaciej - right. and BlackBerry barely does.
we do have vendors who want to ship WebKit with stuff like WAP, WCSS, XHTML MP, ESMP, etc bolted on
apparently due to residual carrier demand in some markets
othermaciej: do you accept patches?
othermaciej: the markets in question include mainland China
hsivonen: we have accepted patches for some of that stuff (as long as it's off by default and minimally intrusive to core code)
othermaciej: isn't XHTML MP support in a backwards-compatible way incompatible with the Web?
MikeSmith: indeed, that is the main one cited

MikeSmith - I think it's the difference in this case between those who helped build it and make it successful, and those who pay membership dues and thus expect a stronger impact upon the steering of goals, resources, often divergent from the former group.
hsivonen: I think that's true for ESMP as well (it's really a "profile" of both the DOM and ECMAScript)
IIRC, the mobile legacy puts pressure against parsing application/xhtml+xml as XML
othermaciej: so I guess it could be argued it's a fairly pragmatic concern given the size of that market
Hixie, WHATWG is effectively a standards body - it just has different rules, procedures, culture, principles etc. than W3C.
hsivonen: I strongly urge people not to ship the stuff that incompatibly changes standard Web APIs
a W3C was/is different from IETF.
tantek: whatwg is a mailing list.
Hixie, WHATWG *has a* mailing list.
it's still a *WG*
tantek: sure, working groups aren't going anywhere
I think standards bodies may be necessary for competing companies to be able to legally collaborate without it being an antitrust violation
What does @role do that @class doesn't except assume support for lots of predefined values...
othermaciej - indeed, and the more open the standards body, the better.
hsivonen: indeed
tantek: but it's not a standards body by any definition anyone would have given 5 years ago. i agree that it's what should happen to standards bodies, though
Hixie, neither is microformats.org
tantek: indeed
Dashiva: @role is sensitive to accessibility API mapping. @class isn't.
hsivonen: But only because we declare it to be
I would say an organization creating a standard is a "standards body", no matter how informally constituted
othermaciej - indeed
Dashiva: well, initially everything is only because so declared to be
after all, for a long time the IETF had no legal existence whatsoever, and even now, its only formal existence is through association with other bodies like ISOC
Dashiva: then the legacy requirements kick in
Dashiva: with @role and ARIA, the legacy has already shipped
othermaciej - "formal existence" may not be necessary for success.
hsivonen: Indeed. But the talk about using the full XHTML2 @role with all its vague uses doesn't have legacy
tantek: does microformats.org exist formally?
tantek: that may be so, although patent law and the paranoia about it can complicate matters
Dashiva: correct
So I'm wondering what's the difference between XHTML2 @role and our previously rejected predefined class names
othermaciej - indeed, and it's good that other orgs have done work (CC PD/CC0, W3C/IETF RF) that can be re-used.
IETF does not have an RF IPR policy
technically they are under RAND with disclosure requirements (though I think individual Working Groups can choose to chart an RF course)

hsivonen microformats.org is an all volunteer community that uses a website (wiki), an IRC channel, and a few mailing lists. not sure if that fulfills anyone's definition of "formal" or not, nor whether it matters whether it does or not.
Dashiva: XHTML2 @role takes non-predefined CURIEs
Dashiva: so XHTML2 @role is like the old HTML5 class with predefined names
role was originally considered to have predefined values plus open-ended non-predefined values
othermaciej: IETF RFC3667 & RFC3668.
Dashiva: where the XHTML2 predefined roles don't have colons and the non-predefined roles are CURIEs
people have at times argued that even the non-predefined values of @role are "more semantic" than any @class value
Well, take JF's statement that @role could be used instead of accesskey
features and functionality are as semantic as you define them to be. it's fairly pointless to argue that use of one attribute is "more semantic" than another in a vacuum.
maybe a useful definition of formal existence is whether it's a non-natural person that can hold copyrights
Wouldn't that require predefined roles?
Dashiva: landmarks?
No, he was talking about it in the XHTML2 context
Dashiva: I haven't read any email from JF this morning yet
Dashiva: that would require predefined roles
once XHTML2 went down the CURIE/namespace path for the role attribute, I gave up on it.
Dashiva: it also doesn't make sense for most application-level keyboard shortcuts
it is good to see that ARIA did not adopt that mistake
keyboard shortcuts are an *exceptionally* difficult problem to solve
tantek: it took some effort to get ARIA out of that hole
hsivonen - thanks for the clarification, I did not realize that.
jgraham: Good job on finding that summary table, by the way. It is indeed quite absurd.
it's amazing how complex technologies that raise the barrier for ease of use could possibly be seriously considered for a technology that supposed to *increase* accessibility
no amount of handwaving that a "role" attribute could solve/replace keyboard shortcuts is going to make it true
A lot of specs would be gone if handwaving had been outlawed :)

can say this from having done *a lot* of work to replace/upgrade "accesskey" with a more flexible/platform-useful "key-equivalent" property. look for "key-equivalent" in this document: http://www.w3.org/Style/css3-updates/css3-ui-comments
"[UPDATE: 'key-equivalent' has been dropped from this version of CSS3-UI.]"
agrees it is a hard problem
precisely, hard enough to drop and not have it hold back other features.

tantek: I don't see anything in either of those RFCs requiring RF patent licensing - the latter specifically mentions that in your disclosure you can state an intent to license a patent under royalty-bearing RAND terms
othermaciej - said nothing about *requiring*
simply *having* an RF policy
so yes, IETF does *have* RF policy
they just don't *require* it
others can require it though
it has an IPR policy
which includes RF as an option
sure, but anyone is always free to license their IP under RF terms
that's undefined
or at least, I've never heard of a standards body that required you to charge royalties for any patents you hold
"RF terms" is specific to each standards body
that's bother to define it
wishes there was Creative Commons equivalent for patent IPR policy.
tantek: isn't that what the Open Web Foundation is for?
open web foundation isn't going to be doing it as far as i can tell
so you could say rel="patent-policy" href="http://creativecommons.org/rf/1" etc.
really wishes there were a reusable RF policy--not a Creative Commons catalog of zillions of different policies to choose from
hsivonen, yes OWF is trying to solve this problem with a contribution template/boilerplate for open web technologies.
the IETF's definition of royalty-free terms is much less precise than the W3C's
Hixie: what is the OWF doing these days, then?
hsivonen, Hixie might not be the right person to ask, he quit the OWF.
they do say there is a preference for royalty-free, which I guess is a policy
othermaciej - agreed their terms are different.
agrees with hsivonen in wishing for *a* reusable RF policy.
has asked Creative Commons for this (a reusable RF policy) publicly, several times in open Q&A.
(over the years)
speaking of open web - anyone hear speak French? there's quite a conversation going (in French) in #openweb
s/hear/here
It seems to me that CC isn't really about Royalty Free or about Freedom in the FSF sense.
karl does, but he might not be around
karlcow/karlushi
CC is pushing for NonCommercial and MoreRights
which are about easy royalty
not royalty-free
hsivonen - the Science Commons effort is working toward RF-like language
it's the closest of the CC efforts towards RF
but it doesn't go far enough (IMHO)
also, Lessig's talks lately have focused on the ease of clearing rights for remixes--not about making remixes simply allowed without rights clearing
IPR policies are different from license agreements though
you can't just slap one on your work unilaterally
othermaciej - why not?
participants have to actually agree to it as grounds for participation
othermaciej - as they do for copyright assignment as well
no different
copyright assignment is a different issue than license agreement
not really. both are IP assignment.
there again, you need active assent of the participant, not just a passive license statement
a license agreement is not an IP assignment at all
it grants you a license for a work under certain conditions
a license is a form of IP assignment.
it's not all, but it is some
the mechanisms are similar enough that a rel to external document solution should work for both
hsivonen: they're making a patent policy for specs made in a few months by small groups with the patent holders being the people who wrote the spec
I don't think a rel link in a document would create a legally binding requirement to assign copyright or disclose or license patents
Hixie: are comments by people who aren't spec editors left as an open IPR injection vector?
organizations that use copyright assignment make contributors actually sign a contract
hsivonen: i don't think any proposals by anyone has any effect on that
Hixie: that sucks
hsivonen: not really

othermaciej - I'm not sure either, but IANAL, nor are you, so all I'm saying is that it *seems* possible - and that therefore it is worth some CC/open-content/standards lawyer's time to try to make it so.
hsivonen: that's a non-issue in practice
hsivonen - it's definitely a problem with mailing lists
hsivonen: patent violations come from primary participants and from people who had patents you didn't know about
where there is no IP requirement for contribution
hsivonen: not from people who have patents and try to inject them into random specs
Hixie - IIRC the Sun/XLink/XPointer problem could be characterized as injection from holder.
a non-wg member sent comments that caused the spec to change to intentionally infringe the commentor's patents?

zcorpan: I checked in the footer change to align with whatwg r3751 and tested it and I just now synced up qa-dev.w3.org:8888 to it for testing. Please check and let me know if anything appears broken.
holy crap, paul posted to the list
Paul does good work.
sigh. http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=HTML&diff=312446147&oldid=prev
hsivonen, but HTML 5 is official lingo, isnt it?
erlehmann: the vote said "HTML 5" but now even the W3C Editor's Draft says "HTML5"
othermaciej: is losing the space something that can be made official by lazy consensus?
hsivonen, impeach the editor ;)
Super Friends asked for the space to be dropped, too.
hsivonen: the whatwg draft seems to be consistently spaceless, as is the latest Editor's Draft
hsivonen: I don't think anyone is asking for the space back, so we could make it a WG decision, but I'm also not sure it is worth the WG's time
hsivonen: I don't know if a WG vote would be binding on Wikipedia in any case
er, WG consensus resolution
I think there will be a lot of confusion about microformats being layered on top and not being directly associated with the markup.
annevk2 why?
are we seriously discussing the consensus on whether there should be a space between the L and the 5 in "HTML5"?
existing success of microformats would seem to refute that hypothesis
sorry, microdata
such similar names :)
annevk2: the spec needs to say something to make that clear
annevk2 - I think microformats have proven out that simple microdata will likely be a success as well.
e.g. on the list people talk about adding semantics by using microdata
but things like <dialog> cannot be introduced with microdata
annevk2 - not true, in fact, there has been work on microformats for conversations
which I expect to do a better job than <dialog>
how do you handle arbitrary markup?
e.g. images, boldening, links, etc. in a phrase a person just typed
othermaciej, nothing is binding for wikipedia.
annevk2 - based on what real world evidence are you asking/implying that handling arbitrary markup is necessary?
presumably ability to cite an authoritative reference is binding, to the extent anything is
see here for current research into conversation/chat examples: http://microformats.org/wiki/chat-examples
feel free to add any more real world evidence you have to that page
wonders if othermaciej's statements in an IRC log are authoritative for Wikipedia purposes
regarding microformats … Hixie, didn't you do a markup study (or planned to do) ?
hsivonen: I would guess next time HTML5 is published by the HTML WG, you could cite the TR link
I'm not sure if they would find the Editor's Draft authoritative
erlehmann - the latest broad data on microformats is available via Yahoo Search monkey
erlehmann: we're recruiting participants now
Hixie, fine to know. :)

tantekc, the logs for this channel often have links at least, in #html-wg pimpbot utters things in colors but the details are not logged, I expect that if Google Wave takes off a little you get more conversations with images, maybe video, etc.
tantekc, if you couly put a time element / attribute in a dialog, would it help ?
I wish more albums that I'm actually interested in had iTunes LP available
tantekc, though simple images is already done today in most IM clients
erlehmann - <dialog> is too broken to be worth discussing what might be necessary to fix it.
tantekc, can you elaborate on that ?
tantekc, I agree we should drop <dialog>
annevk2 - if you can add URLs to illustrative examples of the phenomena you mention to the /wiki/chat-examples page - it would be appreciated.
filed a bug to that effect
hmm, does the xmpp xhtml-im need an overhaul then to keep up with waves and HTML 5 (ha, spaces) ?
annevk2 - feel free to add a +1 to that bug from me.
annevk2, and how do i markup natural conversations then ? going back to <dl>s ?
erlehmann - see the markup here: http://rbach.priv.at/Microformats/IRC/2009-08-29
it makes quite good use of existing HTML 4.01 semantic elements
tantek, and it uses <cite> in a way it was agreed not to in HTML5
erlehmann - HTML5 is broken in that regard
as there is numerous existing uses of <cite> with that semantic
thus HTML5 should be amended to match existing semantic use of <cite>
erlehmann, whatever markup suits your usecase best
that use of <cite> has been well documented and implemented in markup since at least 2005
erlehmann, HTML5 does not have dedicated markup for all use cases, see e.g. the chapters on tag clouds and footnotes
how about making i and cite semantically identical?
annevk2, i use dialog currently, mainly because it is a) simple and b) enables me to state that several people said something simultaneously (am i understanding it right ?)
takkaria, <i> ? sure you are joking
takkaria - it's a smaller change to simply allow <cite> to represent a speaking person, as allowable per HTML 4.01 and in use given the examples.
tantek, i would prefer it too, but to markup quotes i heard.
quotes heard or seen
e.g. in an IRC channel
erlehmann: not being entirely serious
erlehmann, I think you might be using it wrong then
erlehmann, yeah, if you use multiple <dt> followed by a single <dd> you're doing it wrong
erlehmann, so maybe it's not simple :)
annevk2, its not allowed ? :(
erlehmann_, I'm not sure how much clearer I can make it
erlehmann_, you could read the spec
erlehmann, the validator flags it too...
polyglot++
seriously?
It's OK, polyglot is idempotent under addition
http://intertwingly.net/blog/2009/09/08/First-Polyglot-Validator-Check-Deployed#c1252572959
Hixie: "A news organisation's front page ..." - shouldn't that be 'organization' in en-US?
why is <meta http-equiv="Refresh"> considered conforming?
Hixie: was the PDF <link> example intended to link to /en/html ?
Lachy, there's no equivalent
Refresh: ... is equivalent :)
is that implemented?
iirc yes
annevk2, HTTP 302 for most cases
thought only one or two browsers did that
and for the case of a delayed refresh, that should never ever be used
Lachy, disagreed, but I forgot the reason
Lachy: if it's not conforming, people will use setTimeout and location.href instead
but the most common case is using it as <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="0;http://...">
Lachy: the meta is easier to block for users
we should at least warn about it, especially when it's being used for rediection
*redirection
lol Frontweaver
Lachy: That "most common case" seems to be about half of all Refreshes
and the other half are mostly small numbers like 1 and 5 and 3 and 10 etc
and a handful like 1800 which are presumably for auto-refreshing pages, not for redirects
othermaciej: hah, iTunes 9 just crashed on me in WebCore::HTMLTokenizer::parseTag() :-P
(well, actually in the hashtable code, but frame 4 was the tokeniser)
wow, snow leopard's crash reporting is more advanced than leopard's, even
Hixie: what does iTunes 9 use WebCore for?
itunes store, it seems
interesting
I thought iTunes store was using a product-specific markup language without WebKit
has it always been like that or does 9 change things substantially?
per gruber it's 9
ah
assumes that Apple will nevertheless prevent people accessing iTunes Web Store using an ordinary web browser
it's quite sad, really.
I would have made purchases in the iTunes store using Ubuntu if they had a pure Web UI
hsivonen: but since you want iTunes store so badly, you don't use Ubuntu, right?
the css for the itunes store is at http://ax.itunes.apple.com/htmlResources/CFA7/dt-storefront.cssz
so the internet says
zcorpan: well, now we both an Ubuntu box and a Mac at home but the Mac came for a different reason
HOLY SWEET KITTENS
itunes9 has boolean search queries in the smart playlists finally
Ah, I thought you had just discovered a tasty snack

i can reconstruct my playlists so that i just have one "Music Mix" playlist instead of having to construct it using about 9 playlists that are slowly mixed together to do all the "and"ing and "or"ing that i wanted
wonders if he is abnormal because he hardly ever uses playlist features
jgraham: you aren't
i need playlists so that i can get itunes to sync the right podcasts to my ipod
just runs Audacious with a flat list of 247 hours of audio files, and has never had any desire for more organisation
I wish people sarted doing QA with 1.0 UI cale factor
*started
*scale?
Needing to have iTunes is one of the reasons I don't have an iPod.
Isn't 1.0 the default?
Philip`: yes
Philip`: non-1.0
at least 3 bugs in one sentence so far
Ah
I lose
Does Mac OS X, in principle, support differnt scale factors for different screens?
Philip`: i'm up to 427 hours of just (legally-acquired) music, and that's not counting tv shows, movies, podcasts, poetry tracks, audiobooks, etc
Philip`: so i need to narrow it down to sync to my music player
Hixie: You just need a higher-capacity music player
i was going to get the new ipod touch, but it's not really compelling enough to justify $400 or whatever it was

Hixie, in webdatabase, when a database is first opened with "" as the version using: openDatabase("name", "", "Display Name", "1024"); and then next it's opened with "foo" as the version, should it throw an exception?
off the top of my head, yes
Our developer thinks the spec is ambiguous about this because the empty string is used to mean any version is fine
i thought i made this very clear recently
i changed it to have an explicit algorithm
that's what I thought too
Hixie, this requirement makes no sense "If a callback was passed to the method, then let the database's version be the empty string. Otherwise, let its version be the given database version"
it certainly seems odd
I assume it should be saying if the version passed was not the empty string or something
send mail?
ok, will do when I sort out what the spec is supposed to be saying for steps 3 and 4
looks
actually it means exactly what it says
Hixie, it should say something like this:
* Database exists?
- Version passed is empty, or version passed matches existing version? Open database.
- Version passed is not empty and does not match, throw INVALID_STATE_ERR
* Otherwise, database does not exists:
- Create and open the database, let "created" be true. Set the version to the version passed.
(except for missing the "." at the end of the sentence)
but it doesn't make any sense for the value of the version to be set based on whether or not a callback was passed.
yeah, it does
how does it?
because the callback is meant to call changeVersion()
what?
otherwise, two calls to the method at the same time would both call the callback
or, one would call the callback and the other would succeed, but before the callback in the other thread had finished
oh. That just makes things confusing. So if I call openDatabase("db", "foo", "Whatever", 1024, callback); then the version is meant to be set to "" regardless?
only if the database doesn't exist
ok, well we don't support the creation callback yet anyway, so we can ignore that statement for now
so just considering the cases where there is no callback
the steps as written are still not particularly clear
yeah
remind me in 15 minutes
ok
[03:06]  <Dashiva> karl does, but he might not be around
even a better person to ask is people from CreativeCommons who are part of the htmlwg.
indeed CreativeCommons is a way to fill the space in between two extremes: Copyrights to Public Domain, with a variety of options.
man, even since i put my cat's e-mail address in the spec, he gets more spam than i do
I guess if you didn't spy on your cat's inbox it might not bother you so much
if you can train him to filter that spam you could make money from it i'm sure
umm... would you believe "he asked me to redirect his mail to my inbox"?
so that i can read his mail for him, since, you know, he's a cat
you know, most cats don't have email addresses
It sounds like you're jsut checking that he doesn't get email from other would-be owners
he needed an e-mail address to get his livejournal account...
Lachy: ok, updated the steps a bit.
give it a few secs to upload

(interesting aside: my landlady did actually steal someone else's cat by placing a continual supply of food outside the door so that it preferred living in our building to his actual home. Then, when he needed to go to the vet she went and talked to the real owners and somehow convinced them that she should take it to the vet and keep it thereafter)
https://twitter.com/ppk/status/3867647272
hsivonen: so sad
(the "normal" part)
ok i'm starting to notice a bad trend
when i work on e-mails, bug count goes up
when i work on bugs, e-mail count goes up

annevk3: it's for avoiding a speculative future
annevk3: i.e. parsing past </script> ahead of time but committing to that future
is that really a use case?
if authors become aware of these issues they'll prolly just use <script defer> and such
annevk3: it's as much a use case as async has a use case if you formulate it from the author-perceived performace POV instead
annevk3: defer and async make the script execute later in the parse
i thought async was for things that analyze the page and visitors and such
annevk3: I mean a promise that makes things faster without changing the detectable order of parsing and script execution
i.e. execute asap but do not halt parsing
annevk3: it is
i understand what you're proposing, i just don't see the use case
I thought the use case was "be faster"
Although I don't know if it is fater enough to make people actually care
it could be a minor performance benefit but I'd be surprised if it made much difference
annevk3: the use case is having a script set up event handler-triggered code (that the user can trigger during page load) near the top of the page without taking the perf hit of a speculative future
othermaciej: that may be
adds a proposal to cdata escapes
othermaciej: which is why I'm asking if it was considered and I'm not proposing anything at this point
the main useful aspect of async/defer is not having to block parsing on a network load
roc: i'm not planning on mentioning any 3d canvas proposals in this book
you'll have to wait for "dive into html6"
with this proposed feature you have to block at least some aspects of parsing on the network load if the script is external, since the script can use DOM APIs to observe the DOM
my proposal would work for <script><!-- d.w('<script></script>'); d.w('<script></script>'); </script>
it would break for <script><!-- d.w('<scr'+'ipt></script>'); </script>
even <script><!-- d.w('<scr'+'ipt></script>'); --></script>
othermaciej: you'd block the actuation of the DOM ops on the main thread, but the parser thread could continue to produce a non-speculative stream of tree ops
